sn42.6:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nāḷandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.
sn42.6:1.2: Then Asibandhaka’s son the chief went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn42.6:2.1: “Sir, there are western brahmins draped with moss who carry pitchers, immerse themselves in water, and serve the sacred flame.
sn42.6:2.2: When someone has passed away, they truly lift them up, raise them up, and guide them along to heaven.
sn42.6:2.3: But what about the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha: is he able to ensure that the whole world will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm when their body breaks up, after death?”
sn42.6:3.1: “Well then, chief, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
sn42.6:4.2: Take an individual who kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, and have wrong view.
sn42.6:4.3: And a large crowd comes together to offer up supplication and entreaty, circumambulating them with joined palms and saying:
sn42.6:4.4: ‘When this person’s body breaks up, after death, may they be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm!’
sn42.6:4.6: Would that person be reborn in heaven because of their supplications?”
sn42.6:5.1: “Chief, suppose a person were to throw a broad rock into a deep lake.
sn42.6:5.2: And a large crowd was to come together to offer up supplication and entreaty, circumambulating it with joined palms, and saying:
sn42.6:5.3: ‘Rise, good rock! Float, good rock! Float to shore, good rock!’
sn42.6:5.5: Would that broad rock rise up or float because of their supplications?”
sn42.6:5.7: “In the same way, take a person who kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, and have wrong view.
sn42.6:5.8: Even though a large crowd comes together to offer up supplication and entreaty …
sn42.6:5.9: when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
sn42.6:6.2: Take an individual who doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, and have right view.
sn42.6:6.3: And a large crowd comes together to offer up supplication and entreaty, circumambulating them with joined palms and saying:
sn42.6:6.4: ‘When this person’s body breaks up, after death, may they be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell!’
sn42.6:6.6: Would that person be reborn in hell because of their supplications?”
sn42.6:7.1: “Chief, suppose a person were to sink a pot of ghee or oil into a deep lake and break it open. Its shards and chips would sink down, while the ghee or oil in it would rise up.
sn42.6:7.2: And a large crowd was to come together to offer up supplication and entreaty, circumambulating it with joined palms and saying:
sn42.6:7.3: ‘Sink, good ghee or oil! Descend, good ghee or oil! Go down, good ghee or oil!’
sn42.6:7.5: Would that ghee or oil sink and descend because of their supplications?”
sn42.6:8.1: “In the same way, take an individual who doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, and have right view.
sn42.6:8.2: Even though a large crowd comes together to offer up supplication and entreaty …
sn42.6:8.3: when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”
sn42.6:8.4: When he said this, Asibandhaka’s son the chief said to the Buddha,
sn42.6:8.6: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
